dialogues.text: Two days and one night. Excuse me if I plan on changing my clothes. Wendy scans Jon’s sloppy outfit with her eyes. Jon returns his attention to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Sorry about that... My sister... EXT. RENTAL CAR PARKING LOT - DAY a1 Jon loads the trunk of a rented MALIBU while Wendy examines his outfit.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Is that what you're going to wear? Jon looks at his clothes -- a long—john T-shirt and cargo pants -- then back at Wendy, confused.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To pay respect? Irritated, he yanks off his shirt, unzips his bag and digs around for something more appropriate.  32 1s.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I gained some weight.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I didn’t say anything. (looking in his suitcase) Kasia didn’t have you pack a button-down?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: What is this, a goddamn fashion show?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No, it’s just that when someone dies people dréss up. Jon pulls a shirt from deep inside his bag and puts it on

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: She's moving back to Poland.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You and Kasia broke up?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (buttoning up his shirt) Her visa expired. He presents himself to Wendy. She nods in vague approval. Jon SLAMS the trunk CLOSED.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So that’s it. Her visa expires and it's over? They walk to the front of the car, Jon to the driver's si

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: We'll it’s either that or we get married and nobody is ready for that. They climb into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they buckle in

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You've been going out for three years. You're forty-two years old. Don’t you think ——  33 34 35 36 1s.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: ! I really don’t need romantic advice from my little sister at the moment. Let’s just take care of this situation and stay out of each other’s shit. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Well, we're not in therapy right now. We're in real life.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Okay. Geez. Jon starts the engine and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rental car whizzes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jon drives, Wendy shotgun. Ahead is the OPEN ROAD. Above, THE HUGE DESERT SKY. AN EXIT SIGN reads: Sun City.’ Jon takes the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon watch the surreal sights of Sun City sail p INT. /EXT. DORIS METZGER’S STREET - RENTAL CAR 36 They round a corner and park in front of DORIS METZGER’S HOUSE. The siblings stare at the house with trepidation.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: This is going to be weird.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I wonder what he looks like. (remembering something) Oh shoot! I almost forgot. Wendy digs through her purse and pulls out a HALLMARK SYMPATHY CARD.  37 20. WENDY (CONT’D) We have to sign this. They didn’t have a very big selection. Do you think this is okay? (reading the message) These words we hope may ease your loss. Our prayers are with you. Our love. Our thoughts. Jon stares at his sister in disbelief. WENDY (CONT’D) So this is sent in sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jon impatiently grabs the card, leans it against the steering wheel and signs it. EXT. DORIS’S HOUSE - DAY 37 The siblings walk up the path toward the house with sad gift shop offerings: Jon with the string of A FOIL BALLOON that reads, “We Love Dad,” Wendy with CELLOPHANE WRAPPED FLOWERS. ‘They arrive at —-

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN DOOR
dialogues.text: Jon pushes the DOORBELL. No response. Wendy presses her face up to the screen and looks inside. WENDY'S POV of THE FOYER —~ Her eyes land on an ALUMINUM WALKER. Jon KNOCKS lightly on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Hello. Dad?

dialogues.speaker: EDUARDO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Coming! Eduardo appears on the other side of the screen door. It' obvious from his surprised expression and the fact that h doesn’t open the door right away that something is amiss.

dialogues.speaker: EDUARDO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must be Leonard's kids.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: EDUARDO
dialogues.text: Didn't you get my message?  38 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jon and Wendy sit side-by-side on the couch with uncertai expressions on their faces. The pathetic balloon floats above them. FLOWERS and SYMPATHY CARDS abound. Across from them -- NANCY LACHMAN, 47, sits with her husband, BILL, 48, who nurses a Heineken. Their children, HOPE and FAITH are nearby watching “SpongeBob SquarePants” on the T.V. Eduardo hovers.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: The hospital is just five minutes away. And don’t worry. It’s nothing serious. He'd been feeling kind of faint and what with the toileting incident and all, the doctor thought a few tests were in order.

dialogues.speaker: EDUARDO
dialogues.text: I told him I didn’t think there was anything wrong with that man’s mind. That it was just Lenny being Lenny. But he insisted on taking a look for himself.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (to Nancy) So when did he go there?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: um --

dialogues.speaker: EDUARDO
dialogues.text: Just last night. I’m sorry you didn’t get my message.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Well, I guess we should be going then. Jon and Wendy rise, awkwardly gathering their things. Wendy remembers their card and hands it to Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We're really sorry about your mom.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: ‘Thank you. Bill gives Nancy a look, encouraging her to speak up.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh, Jon, Wendy... One more thing. Before you go. Please, sit. I just want to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NANCY (CONT’D) (getting choked up) You know, we love Lenny. He's been like family to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon sit again, smiling gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he’s not really our family. He's yours. Jon and Wendy's smiles evaporate.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, I hope you'll be able to find some place nice for him.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: She means a place where he can live.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: He lives here.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That’s correct. Your father has been living off the charity of our family for quite some time.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Bill -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Jon instantly understands what's happening, but Wendy is baffled.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Why would you say charity, Bill? Doris asked my father to come live with her as a boyfriend not a boarder. They were a couple. They were together for over twenty years. Nancy starts to cry. Twelve-year-old Hope drifts over and protectively attaches herself to her mother’s leg. She st suspiciously at Wendy and Jon. Wendy smiles nervously at glaring child. JON (CONT’D) You can’t just throw the man out on the street. He has a right to live here. Legally speaking. It’s a common law marriage at this point.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well, not exactly

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (glancing at her husband) Not in front of the kids, Bill. Bill rises, hitches up his pants and picks up his VALISE.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (to Jon) Why don’t we step outside. Jon gets up warily and hands off the balloon to Wendy. Bi leads Jon across the room, rolls open a GLASS DOOR and th two men step out into a PATIO AREA. Bill slides the door closed behind them. Wendy and Nancy sit silently watching them. After a moment, Nancy turns and smiles at Wendy. Wendy smiles back. ‘It is excruciatingly awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Jon talk animatedly. Bill pulls a DOCUMENT from his valise and hands it to Jon. Jon puts on a PAIR OF GLASSES. Bill takes a swig from a bottle of Heineken and watches him read.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: It's called a Non-marital Agreement. It's something Doris had drafted up years ago. EXT. DORIS’ HOUSE - DAY 40 AGITATED HAND-HELD as Wendy and Jon march down the path, their balloon in tow. Jon grips a copy of the document.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: It’s like a pre-nup without the nup. It says that even though they live together they have no legal obligation to each other. That everything is separate. And basically that Dad has no right to any of her property. I bet they’ve already got the place listed.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Did you notice that there wasn’t one picture of us anywhere? It’s like we don’t even exist.  41 42 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon hustle down a long hall, VISITOR STICKERS affixed to their shirts. They each carry a cup from Starbucks. Their foil balloon bounces overhead. Checking the room numbers, they slow down as they approach the one they seek. Jon makes sure Wendy is ready before he reaches for the knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A T.V. suspended from the ceiling plays a LOUD GAME SHOW. Jon and Wendy quietly enter and step around a curtain to find -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENNY, asleep, with an IV in his arm. They stand there a moment, haggardly staring at their

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: estranged and ailing father. Then

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Wen?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What? Jon nods at something on the other side of the bed. Wendy looks and SEES A BAG WITH DARK YELLOW LIQUID hanging from a stand.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Dad's taking a piss. Wendy and Jon stare blankly as the liquid level RISES. A strange pause. Then A BURST OF APPLAUSE from the 7.V. Wendy and Jon look up at the T.V. It’s JEOPARDY. They watch for a long spaced out moment. In unison, they take a sip from their Starbucks. Then—

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.8)
dialogues.text: Where the hell have you been? Wendy and Jon turn to face Lenny.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hi Dad. Hi. How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: ‘They've had me hog-tied for two days. can't you see?  25. Lenny becomes agitated and starts to thrash around. His sheet slides off to reveal RESTRAINTS holding his wrists and ankles. Wendy and Jon look at each other, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We just got here. We came pretty much straight from the airport. It's Wendy and Jon. Lenny eyes his children.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: I know who you are. You’re the late ones. You're late! You weren't here! And this is what they do, see. Lenny pulls violently against his restraints.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Dad! Dad! Stop. Lenny doesn’t stop. He's wild.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (shrinking away from the bed) Jon, go get somebody.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: You weren’t here, I said! Nobody!

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (grabbing his father’s arm) Dad! Lenny stops momentarily and stares up at his son. A tiny flicker of fear in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We weren't here because we live on the east coast. Remember? We haven't seen you in a long time. We came here to help you.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: So do something. You're the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He's not that kind of doctor, Dad. He's a professor.  26.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) I’m gonna go get somebody. Jon goes to the door and exits.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: I thought my boy was a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Doctor of Philosophy. PhD. Jon teaches college.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Medicine?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No. Drama. He teaches theater.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Like Broad-way? Zasu Pitts?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No, like... “Theater of Social Unrest.” Stuff like that. He’s doing a book on Bertolt Brecht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings open. In walks Jon with a NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I/1l untie him only if he promises to be good. He can’t be trying to get out of bed by himself. You gonna be good, Mr. Savage?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Dad, are you gonna be good? If you're not good they won't untie you. Lenny stays still and stares at his son like an obedient dog who wants his reward.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You can’t go pulling on everything, now. (re: IV tube) This here is for your own good. This is your food. (untying his hands and feet) We can’t have him climbing out on his own. He’s unsteady and he can fall.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: We'll keep an eye on him.  43 27. The nurse exits the room. Now untied, Lenny looks up at Wendy and Jon suspiciously. Everyone just stands there, unsure what's supposed to happen next.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: vascular dementia or multi-infarct, usually follow one or more strokes. But I don’t see any signs of a stroke here. No tumor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DARKNESS. Then, A DOOR OPENS allowing some light into A ROOM. A DOCTOR, Wendy and Jon enter.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: But the disinhibition; the aggression, the “masked face” with the blank stare we talked about; slowness of speech, memory loss. These are all fairly good indicators. CLICK. CLICK. CLICK. Lights stutter on and —~ A SERIES OF MRI PICTURES OF LENNY’S BRAIN -~ appear one at a time as wall-mounted light boxes are switched on. We are in ——

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Is it like Alzheimer’s?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: There are lots of different illnesses that cause dementia and I’m not prepared to make a diagnosis yet, but to my mind your father’s symptoms seem more characteristic of Parkinson’s Disease.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: So what do we have to look forward to?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: If I’m right, then tremors -- when the limb is at rest. A shuffling walk. Freezing up, unable to initiate movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the doctor speaks, Wendy and Jon look around at the dark mysterious images of their father’s brain. The HUMMING OF THE LIGHT BOXES increases, eventually drowning out the doctor's voice.  44 45 46 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘The BLUE AND YELLOW SIGN glows against the desert sky, accompanied by a DUET, sung by an older man and woman.

dialogues.speaker: DUET
dialogues.text: You make me feel so young. You make me feel that spring is sprung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG continues over ~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon roll their bags toward their room. PALM TRE silhouetted against the sky sway in the desert breeze.

dialogues.speaker: DUET
dialogues.text: Every time I see you grin, I'm such a happy individual...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BURT & LIZZY -- a low-rent Steve and Eydie Gormet are singing the duet we've been hearing. The AUDIENCE OF RETIREES love them.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon are drinking sodas and eating nuts. Wendy leafs through a pamphlet called “Dementia” while Jon peruses “Parkinson's Disease.”

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Maybe Dad didn’t abandon us. Maybe he just forgot who we were.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I’m going to give Brian Deener a call.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: A friend of mine. ‘Teaches in the English Department. He just put his mother in a nursing home near campus... (to bartender) can we get some more nuts? Wendy looks at Jon, stunned.  29.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: A nursing home?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yeah. What?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I wasn’t thinking about putting him in a nursing home.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Well, what were you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't know, but I wasn’t thinking that.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Well, what then?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't know, Jon! I just said. It’s just not what I was picturing is all.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Where else is he going to live, Wen? I mean really -- what’s the alternative? You want to change Dad’s diapers and wipe his ass? I don’t. An OLDER COUPLE at a neighboring table look over. Wendy smiles at them and lowers her voice.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He doesn’t need diapers, Jon.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Well what do you think that catheter was?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That's just because he’s in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Look, even if they did let Dad stay here, he'd still need somebody to take care of him. And you know we can’t afford that. And you heard the nurse, Dad falls. He's disoriented —~

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Dad hasn't fallen since we've been here.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: That's ‘cause he’s lying down in a hospital! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t make me out to be the evil brother who is putting our father away against your will. We're doing this together, right? Wendy pokes her ice with a cocktail straw.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What about those places?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: What places?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Like Aunt Gertie.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: That’s assisted living. I’m not sure Dad/1l get into one of them. Gertie was pretty independent, remember? She was also rich. (pause) Look, there’s no one else here to help us with this. It’s just us. We have to do this thing together, right? (no response) Wendy?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No, yeah, you're right, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Okay. So, I’m going to call United and try to get the first flight out of here tomorrow morning so I can get back and start looking for a place that'll take him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: You're going to have to stay here and hold down the fort until I find something.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: By myself?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Wendy, this is not the time to regress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Whhhaaaaa!  47 48 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCILLE BALL bawls like a baby in an episode of I LOVE LUCY. Across from the TV, Wendy is in bed, sleeping. Mixed in with the sound of the television, we hear Jon talking -- upset mumbling coming from the bathroom. Wendy's eyes flutter open. WENDY'S Pov -— A sliver of Jon through the bathroom door. He's on the phone. We can’t make out all the words, but it’s clear that he’s having some kind of disagreement with his girlfriend. After a moment, he hangs up. HOLD ON him standing silent and still over the sink. ‘Then, a spasm o short little breaths and he starts to cry. Wendy is moved by this vision of her brother’s vulnerabil She closes her eyes again, as we —~ FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (hushed) Hey, Wendy. Wen. Wen. FADE IN TO SEE WENDY’S POV of Jon, standing over the bed, all dressed with his luggage hanging off him. It’s still dark outside.

dialogues.speaker: BLEARY-EYED WENDY
dialogues.text: twisted up in bedclothes looking up at Jon.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I'm going. Wendy sleepily watches as Jon pulls out some cash and places it on the bureau.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘That should take care of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: ‘Thanks. Jon nods and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm fine. I'll call you. Jon leaves, pulling the door closed behind him, leaving Wendy in the dark, her anxious face barely visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC PUMPS. ON THE T.V. an exercise program plays. Wendy is in her underwear, struggling to follow along. She feels pathetic, but pushes herself to do it anyway. INT. LARRY’S APARTMENT - DAY 50 CLOSE ON A RINGING PHONE. In the background, Larry looks up from his spot at the kitchen table. Before he can get up, his wife ANNIE answers.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hello? INT. BEST WESTERN ROOM - DAY sl Wendy, sweaty from her work-out, holds the phone, but doesn’t speak.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello? Who is it? Hello? Hello? ‘The CLICKING SOUND OF HANGING UP. Wendy stares into space, hating her life. EXT. DORIS’ HOUSE - DAY 52 A SMALL BANNER that says "OPEN HOUSE” hangs out front flapping in the dry breeze. INT. DORIS’ HOUSE - DAY 53 SEVERAL ELDERLY COUPLES ARE being shown around by a REAL ESTATE AGENT who does her pitch. The CAMERA LOCATES an open doorway and peeks into --  54 55 56 57 33.

dialogues.speaker: THE GUEST ROOM
dialogues.text: where Wendy can be seen unzipping a large, cheap SUITCASE. She props it open on a couch. We MOVE INSIDE the room as Wendy pushes open the accordion doors of a large closet to reveal a sad assortment of MEN'S CLOTHES. After a moment reflecting upon the sorry state of her father’s life, Wendy removes an armful of clothes, hangers and all, and dumps them into the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: A DRAWER OPENS, LINED WITH FLORAL CONTACT PAPER
dialogues.text: Miscellaneous toiletries slide around inside. Wendy's hand rifles through the items, removing anything “Male”. A MEDICINE CABINET OPENS, PACKED WITH PHARMACEUTICALS -. Wendy's hand quickly extracts all the vials on which Leon Savage's name appears. The cabinet CLOSES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Wendy re-opens the cabinet. Her fingers drift over the pill bottles until they locate one that says: Doris Metzger -- and below that: Percocet. Wendy takes the bottle and shuts the cabinet again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE MIRROR, we see her remove a pill, pop it in her mouth and wash it back with a handful of water.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Wendy drags suitcases toward the front door, passing the REAL ESTATE AGENT who, having released the group of buyers, rattles around the house by herself, talking on her cell phone. She sees Wendy, covers her phone and whispers

dialogues.speaker: REAL ESTATE AGENT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy, feeling the narcotic effects of the Percocet, lean against the window and looks out at the strange desert landscape blurring by.  58 59 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUITCASES filled with Lenny’s belongings are parked around the room. Wendy sits on the bed looking through the contents of an OLD BRIEFCASE -- bundles of LETTERS, yellowed children’s DRAWINGS and an assortment of WALLET-SIZED SCHOOL PORTRAITS of Wendy and Jon. The PHONE RINGS and Wendy answers.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bitterly cold. Jon wears a MASSIVE PARKA and paces with his cell phone pressed to his ear. His breath is visible and rushes out of his mouth as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Hi. INTERCUT between Wendy and Jon.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh my god, Jon, you're not going to believe it. I just found this stash of pictures of us from Dewey Elementary. 1 can’t believe he kept them all this time. She fishes out a goofy photo of Jon.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am looking at the funniest picture of you, right now...

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (shivering, but amused) oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: With a big mouth full of metal. How come you got braces, they never gave me braces?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Have you ever looked at my teeth? ‘They're still crooked.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘cause Dad never paid the bills and the orthodontist was so pissed, he pulled the braces out of my mouth before my teeth were fixed. Wendy snort-laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, I think I found something.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: A place with an opening that can take him right away.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What kind of place?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) A facility for older people. In this country we call them nursing homes.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I thought we were gonna try assisted living.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: They're not going to take him in assisted living, Wendy! Let’s be real. He’s got dementia.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well don’t lead with that.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Look, if it’s any consolation -- this place -- they don’t call it a nursing home.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What do they call it?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: A Rehabilitation Center. It’s called The valley View. The CAMERA PANS AWAY to reveal that Jon is standing near the very place he speaks of. It is a grim institutional building with a sign out front, The Valley View Rehabilitation Center.  60 61 36.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: ‘That sounds nice. Is it?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: It’s a nursing home, Wendy!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Does it smell?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yes, Wendy it smells. ‘They all smell. Look, this place has an empty bed, they take Medicaid and it’s close to my house. Believe me, once you get inside these places, they’re all the same. Wendy holds the phone unable to speak for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wendy?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Make sure to have a coat for him when we get there. He doesn’t have any warm clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viewed from behind, Wendy hustles down an empty corridor. INT. LENNY’S HOSPITAL ROOM - DAWN 61 Wendy enters and sees the empty hospital bed and no sign of anything else at first. Then she steps deeper into the room and turns to find

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny, sitting in a wheelchair, all ready to go. He’s bee dresséd by the nurses and it shows. He wears a FLANNEL SH with SUSPENDERS, TROUSERS and a BASEBALL CAP, like a kid dressed for school by somebody else’s mother- Wendy is struck by the poignancy of this but moves on with the business at hand.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hi Dad. After a little delay, Lenny pulls his attention away from the wall he’s been staring at and stiffly twists his head to look at his daughter.  62 37.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Hi ya. There is a glimmer in his eye, a tiny smile on his face. Lenny seems to have some vague feeling of hope, not unlik way a dog senses that his beloved family is planning a vacation and he might be taken along. Wendy removes Lenny baseball cap and gives him a kiss on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: How're you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Not bad. She tosses the cap on the bed and begins unclipping his suspenders. Lenny does not resist.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You don't need these, right, Dad? Not your style. They're like Grandpa Walton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE NURSES’ STATION -- Wendy finishes signing the HOSPITAL RELEASE FORMS, folds papers in half and shoves them into one of the plastic ba hang off the back of Lenny’s wheelchair. A NURSE in her 50's hands over Lenny’s medical records, medications and instructions. Wendy dumps the pill bottles into her purse.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Here. Lemme give you some of these. The nurse looks over her shoulder to make sure she is unobserved, then pulls out a half a dozen ADULT DIAPERS. Wendy’s eyes widen. NURSE (CONT’D) They don’t like us to give this stuff away, but you might need it. She hands the diapers to Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: ‘Thanks. She stuffs the diapers in her bag.  63 64 38.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (rousing herself) Okay. Wendy turns the wheelchair, pointing it toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ready, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Have a good trip, Mr. Savage. (whispering to Wendy) Good luck. Lenny waves with a small wiggle of his fingers. Wendy rolls him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We MOVE toward the aircraft. TWO FLIGHT ATTENDANTS stand at the far end by the cabin door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy pushes Lenny’s wheelchair. TWO AIRLINE EMPLOYEES march behind her in matching uniforms. They arrive at the CABIN DOOR, where the flight attendants greet them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of nowhere, the two airline employees produce A FOLDE METAL CONTRAPTION and pull open a series of METAL FLAPS, transforming it into A BOARDING CHAIR. Unlike a wheelchai it’s narrow enough to fit down the aisle of an airplane. Wendy stands by and watches as they transfer Lenny to the boarding chair. Lenny’s beseeching eyes are fixed on Wendy as he is handled by these human furniture movers. They arrange his arms across his chest, straight-jacket style, and strap him in. Wendy looks on helplessly as Lenny, not unlike a crate on a supermarket dolly, is TILTED BACK, SPUN AROUND and WHEELED onto the aircraft, BACKWARDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy lumbers down the aisle following behind Lenny, banging passengers with her bags.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Sorry. Excuse me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 39. WENDY'S POV of the SEATED PASSENGERS stealing looks at her and her father as they make their humiliating pilgrimage to COACH.

dialogues.speaker: AT THEIR ASSIGNED SEATS --
dialogues.text: Lenny is helped into the aisle seat while Wendy shoves their bags into the overhead compartment. She squeezes past her father and collapses into the WINDOW SEAT. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: ON WENDY
dialogues.text: staring out the window. Suddenly ~~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THWACK! Lenny slams his hand down on his tray. He's agitated, scattering what remains of his SNACK BOX. He begins to tug and fumble with his SEATBELT.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, what are you doing? Lenny turns stiffly and looks at Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: (flat) Bath-room.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: (agitated and loud)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Okay, Dad. Calm down. Let’s just wait for the lady to come and take our stuff away so we can --

dialogues.speaker: NOW
dialogues.text: Lenny pulls violently on his seatbelt. wendy glances over her shoulder and sees the CONCERNED FACES of neighboring passengers.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (mortified) Okay. Okay, Dad we'll take care of it.  66 40. She frantically clears off his tray table and latches it to the seatback. Lenny tries to lift himself up.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not yet, Dad. Just wait a second. Wendy climbs over her father and stumbles into the aisle. She tucks her hair behind each ear and readies herself.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, Dad ~ Wendy takes Lenny’s hands and helps him shimmy into the aisle. They stand there, facing each other and holding hands like mismatched dance partners. Wendy starts inching backwards, slowly leading Lenny toward the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's good, Dad. Suddenly, Lenny stops. His face distressed.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, what? Wendy looks down and lets out a TINY GASP. A WIDE SHOT reveals that Lenny’s pants have collapsed around his ankles -- he’s standing in the middle of the airplane in his diapers. As word spreads, passengers throughout the cabin crane their necks to get a look.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's okay, Dad. Don’t worry. We're fine. Seems like Lenny needed those suspenders after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jon's ten year-old TOYOTA CORROLA idles in front of the arrival area. The windows are frosted and steamed up. Jon sits behind the wheel listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED on NPR. Very civilized. Then --

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DRIVER'S SIDE WINDOW -
dialogues.text: A HAND APPEARS, wiping away the snow and frost to reveal a frantic Wendy.  al.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Jon!

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (rolling down the window) Hey, Wen. Wendy hands some PATENT LEATHER LOAFERS through the window.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whats this?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: They're Dad's. I can’t get them back on his feet. They swelled up. (moving toward the trunk) Pop the trunk. Wendy tosses the bags in, slams it shut and returns to Jon’s window.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Inside. (holding out her hand) ‘The coat. Jon pulls a MASSIVE PARKA from the back seat and shoves it through the window.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I can’t leave the car unattended.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Pine.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Is everything alright? Wendy looks at Jon with a flat expression, then pivots around and leaves with the parka. Jon looks out the window. THROUGH THE MASSIVE PLATE GLASS WINDOW OF THE TERMINAL —- He sees Lenny sitting in an airport wheelchair, parked by the luggage. Lenny seems to be the only person in the whole terminal that isn’t moving. ON JON -- watching, the image sinking in -- his father is a helpless old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all packed in, Wendy in the back with their carry ons. Lenny’s face is barely visible inside the fur-lined hood of the parka. The windshield wipers squeak and push snow from the glass. After a few moments of uncomfortable silence, Jon steals a glance at his father.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Been a while since you've seen this, huh Dad? Snow. What d’you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny stares ahead. After a moment

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Lousy.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s always like this this time of year.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Not the weather. Your driving. It’s lousy. Never could drive. Wendy starts cracking up in the backseat. Then Jon joins

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (amused) What ‘re you a bunch a dummies? The hell you laughing at? This only makes Jon and Wendy laugh louder. Now Lenny starts laughing. Everybody is laughing like crazy. Eventually, the laughter dies down and trails off. A brief silence, then -- LENNY (CONT’D) Did anyone of you remember to tell Doris I’m outta town for a while? She gets worried. Wendy and Jon nervously glance at each other in the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, Dad, I took care of that. Nothing to worry about.  69 70 7 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commercial strip: Low buildings, out-dated stores, fast food restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pull up in front of the VALLEY VIEW, the ILLUMINATED SIGN flickers. Wendy takes in the building an its surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Where's the view?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy, Jon and Lenny (once again in a borrowed wheelchair) are being lead through the facility by a heavy-hipped African-American nurse, MS. ROBINSON. She's tired but not unkind. Wendy and Jon carry suitcases and plastic bags with Lenny’s things. Lenny cradles a bag in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: MS. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: We don’t usually admit new residents after five o’clock, but I understand you came a long way. Isn't that right Mr. Savage?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: What'd ya say?

dialogues.speaker: MS. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (louder) You came a long way.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Not too bad. WENDY'S MOVING Pov -~ The staff is scarce at this down-at-the-heels facility. Residents are lightly scattered about the communal spaces. Some are parked in hallways. Others wander. As they pass A LAUNDRY CART filled with dirty sheets, Wendy takes a whiff. Her nostrils flare. Lenny seems unaware of what exactly is happening. His expression is peaceful, almost dreamy. A CAT darts across the hall.  72 73 44.

dialogues.speaker: MS. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: That's Winston, we call him the Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER HALLWAY -
dialogues.text: Ms. Robinson leads Lenny, Wendy and Jon to -~

dialogues.speaker: ROOM B-26
dialogues.text: She knocks lightly. No response. She turns the knob and looks back at the Savages ——

dialogues.speaker: MS. ROBINSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we are. She pushes open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pass through the small entranceway

dialogues.speaker: MS. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (pointing things out) The bathroom and the closet here you'll share with Mr. Sperry. Ms. Robinson ushers everyone past A CURTAINED-OFF BED SPACE and into the back half of the room. Lenny, Wendy and Jon stop and look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS ACROSS a hospital-style bed, an orange vinyl chair and a window where among sloping telephone wires, the top branches of a bare tree can be seen. MS. ROBINSON (CONT’D) These are just the bare essentials, of course. Ohce you move in, you can’ dress it up anyway you want. (poking her head through the courtesy curtain) Mr. Sperry? You want to meet your new neighbor? Mr. Savage? After a moment, she pulls the curtain open to expose MR. SPERRY, 80, in a hospital gown reading a large print Agatha Christie mystery. He greets the family with a stiff wave and a crooked smile.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SPERRY
dialogues.text: Hi there.  4 45. An odd suspended moment as everyone looks at the old man in the bed. And then, just like that, Ms. Robinson closes the curtain. Show's over.

dialogues.speaker: MS. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: I'll leave you alone to look around and get yourselves together. (low to Jon) I need you to sign some papers. 1/11 send someone in to get him ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Wendy is putting Lenny’s clothes into a bureau. An aide enters -- JIMMY, 30, a skinny, handsome Nigerian guy with dreadlocks. oIMMY (Nigerian accent) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hi. oIMMY You're gonna need to write down his name on all his things so nothing gets lost. You like red or green? Jimmy produces TWO LAUNDRY MARKERS. She reaches for the red one.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Lenny) Good evening sir, I’m Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Leonard Savage. omMMy Good to meet you.

dialogues.text: Ditto. oIMMY (to Wendy) Make sure to include B-26, the room number. Lemme show you. Jimmy steps up to the bureau, takes one of Lenny’s t-shir and writes on the inside collar: L. JIMMY (CONT’D) You ready for a good night's sleep? Gimme your arms up in the air. Come on. Up. Up like you're under arrest. Lenny lifts his arms stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good man. You ever done time, Mr. Savage? Lenny laughs. Jimmy pulls his shirt off over his head. 75 THE HALLWAY OUTSIDE LENNY’S ROOM - LATER 75 Mrs. Robinson is giving Jon and Wendy final words of advi

dialogues.speaker: MS. ROBINSON
dialogues.text: (hushed voice) It’s a good idea not to make too big of a thing when you leave for the first time. Just go real casual. No big good-byes. You don’t want to get him agitated before he adjusts and settles into his new home.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE ROOM -
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon pull on their coats. Lenny watches them from bed.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: So everything okay, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Okay then we'll see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Good night Dad. Jon stands by as Wendy bends down and kisses her father good night. They head toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Hey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon stop and turn around, expecting the worst.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Don't forget to tip the girl on the way out. ‘They expect it in a nice hotel like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jon and Wendy walk quickly and silently toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heavy door flies open and Wendy and Jon hurl themselves from the building and crunch across the parking lot. Breath plumes out of their mouths like smoke. It’s freezing cold. Halfway across the lot, Wendy stumbles to a halt and ERUPTS into a fit of tears.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: What, Wen? Through heaving sobs --

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He didn’t even -- know -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: were taking him.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: He still doesn’t know. He doesn’t know where he is.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We're horrible, horrible, horrible people, Jon. Horrible, horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. JON’S HOUSE - NIGHT 79 The car pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Jon and Wendy shuffle into the darkened foyer. Jon flips on the LIGHTS. Wendy looks around.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: PILES of BOOKS, NEWSPAPERS and MAGAZINES. Heaps of hand labeled VIDEO AND AUDIO TAPES stacked all around the TV.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It looks like the Unibomber lives here.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I’ve been doing a lot of research for the book. The couch is actually pretty comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Great... Where is it? Wendy watches as Jon removes stacks of books that nearly the couch. She joins him and starts to move books as well

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Those need to go over here, actually. Jon takes the books from Wendy and puts them in a specific place. When Jon turns around, he discovers that Wendy is lifting more books from the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (taking books from her) It doesn’t look like it, I know, but there's actually a system to all of this.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (with raised hands) Oooch-kay. Wendy moves out of the way and watches as her brother obsessively re-organizing the books. INT. JON’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 1 Wendy flips on a light and enters. She takes A PILLOW from Jon’s unmade bed, then notices a PRESCRIPTION PILL BOTTLE on his nightstand. She picks up the bottle, yelling downstairs --

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Jon, what's Zocor?

dialogues.speaker: JON, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Get out of my room, Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Is that for depression?

dialogues.speaker: JON, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: It's for cholesterol.  82 49.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You have high cholesterol?

dialogues.speaker: JON, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: ves! Now Wendy notices A SHOPPING BAG full of MAIL AND BROCHURES. She kneels down to take a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Is this all your nursing home research?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Wendy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The couch has been made, but Jon is still organizing his books, apparently unable to stop. Wendy shuffles in, carrying the pillow and the shopping bag she found upstairs. She tosses the pillow on the couch and sits dow to dig through the bag.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Most of these aren’t even open.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I got on some list, they just keep coming. Wendy pulls out a large, full-color brochure and begins to leaf through it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hill Haven. This looks nice.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: It's in Vermont. I really wish you hadn't brought that down. Wendy stuffs the brochure back into the bag and climbs under the blanket. She squirms around uncomfortably, then digs under the cushions and pulls out a A CRUSHED PAPERBACK.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Jon. Jon looks up. Wendy holds the book out to him.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: What is it?  50.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (pointedly) “Theater of the Absurd." Jon retrieves the book, puts it in its proper place and continues to hover over his piles.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you going to stop?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, sorry. Jon begins SWITCHING OFF the lights. As he does, he notices his sister's troubled expression.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're doing the right thing, Wen. We're taking better care of the old man than he ever did of us.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (not sure) I know.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (climbing the stairs) Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: ‘night. A RADIATOR HISSES as Wendy lies in the dark with her eyes wide open. A note of MUSIC, then —-

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: We know that this is one of the toughest decisions of your life

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: IMAGES OF CRASHING SURF on a TV.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What to do when the parent who took care of you can no longer take care of themself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy sits in the dark watching a PROMOTIONAL VIDEOTAPE for GREENHILL MANOR -- a luxury nursing home. She's eating a bowl of cereal and the floor around her is covered in nursing home brochures.  83

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We know how hard this can be, that’s why here at Greenhill Manor we are committed to providing the highest quality of care to our residents... ‘The CAMERA MOVES IN ON WENDY as she watches, transfixed. ON T.V.: images of A BEAUTIFULLY LANDSCAPED ESTATE that looks more like a New England Prep school than a nursing home. Words appear and disappear over the images. Words like: Commitment. Community. Compassion. SENTIMENTAL MUSIC plays over gauzy photos of HAPPY SENIORS being attended to by a caring STAFF. EXT. JON’S HOUSE - DAY 83 From inside the car -- AN ICE AND SNOW PACKED WINDSHIELD. Wendy sits inside and watches. ‘The camera MOVES TOWARD the windshield, past Wendy, through the hole Jon has created, past Jon, past the tops of the trees and into

dialogues.speaker: THE WINTER SKY
dialogues.text: ORCHESTRAL MUSIC SWELLS, a ghostly black and white FRED ASTAIRE appears and begins to SING, as though performing for us from the great beyond.

dialogues.speaker: FRED ASTAIRE
dialogues.text: Heaven. I'm in heaven. And my heart beats so that I can hardly speak... TILT DOWN to reveal -~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks particularly bleak on this snowy winter day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music continues, but now it emanates from a BOOMBOX, suddenly sounding thin and tinny. A ROOMPUL OF RESIDENTS with their arms over their heads move in SLOW MOTION in rhythm to the song.  87 52. They’re taking part in an exercise class overseen by A PHYSICAL THERAPIST. Lenny is among them, skeptical, but playing along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon sit across from an ADMINISTRATOR. Fred Astaire can be heard in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: (referring to a file) Well, it looks like all his Medicaid is squared away. And as far as his advance directive — The Administrator pops a pen in her mouth, holding it between her teeth as she leafs through some papers.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hey, I take that. The administrator looks up.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing) on your pen. The administrator looks at her pen. It is imprinted with an ad for Xanax.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For anxiety. Not all the time. Just when I need it. The administrator smiles vaguely and returns to her work. Jon looks at his sister sideways.

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: So here's the Health Care Proxy we talked about and the Living Will material. We'll need these signed both by you and your father. She holds the papers over the desk. Jon and Wendy both reach for them, but the administrator hands them to Jon. Wendy feels slighted. ADMINISTRATOR (CONT’D) ‘The only other thing missing is the paperwork regarding funeral arrangements. We'll need to know about your father’s burial or cremation plans. Wendy and Jon stare at her, taken aback.  88 89 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Savages sit in a booth. Jon is holding A HEARING AID between two fingers showing it to his father like it’s an exotic bug.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: You see Dad, if you switch this little thing here you can change the volume and you can turn it off. Jon hands the hearing aid to Lenny. Lenny puts it in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How's that? Is it a good level?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. An awkward pause. Wendy and Jon exchange nervous looks.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Uh, Dad we need to talk about a couple of ‘things.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We don’t want you to take it in the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: It's just some questions that'll make everything easier in the long run. Lenny nods reasonably. Wendy nervously begins ~~

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: okay, if um, in the event that something happens, how would you, um, you know, want us to, uh-

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Dad, suppose you were in a coma?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Jon!  54.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Would you want a breathing machine to keep you alive?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: What kind of question is that?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: It's a question that we should know the answer to -- in case.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: In case what?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: In case something happens.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to Lenny) But nothing's happening right now. Nothing new.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: It's just procedure. Something they want for their records.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: ‘The people that run the place. The valley View.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: What the hell kind of hotel is it?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Unplug me.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: What?  55.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: (loud and clear) Pull the plug. Nearby CUSTOMERS look in their direction. Jon and Wendy lower their voices.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: okay, Dad. $0, now, once we unplug you.

dialogues.text: i'm dead.

dialogues.text: Right. And then we...

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.text: What do we do with you? Lenny looks at both his children and then he breaks into a fit of wheezing laughter.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: (talking through laughter) You bury me. What're you a bunch of idiots? You bury me. Lenny continues laughing. Unnerved by his outburst, Wendy and Jon stare silently at their father, unsure whether to laugh or cry. 90 INT. JON’S HOUSE - FOYER - NIGHT 90 The front door opens. dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: ‘That’s okay.  56.

dialogues.text: Jon didn’t tell you?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KASIA
dialogues.text: ‘That I was coming. ‘Typical. Just then, Jon appears at the front door, carrying a BIG LAUNDRY BAG.

dialogues.speaker: KASIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Jon) You just gave your sister heart attack. She didn’t expect to find Polish woman in her brother's home.

dialogues.text: (to Wendy) I told you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JON

dialogues.speaker: KASIA
dialogues.text: very early. We should leave by 6:30 at latest.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (0S)
dialogues.text: Okay. Kasia looks at Wendy, shrugs sadly and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: KASIA
dialogues.text: It's back to Krakow for Kasia.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Jon told me. I’m sorry. Kasia walks to the stairs, pausing at the bottom.

dialogues.text: Eggs fry on the stove. Kasia tends to them with a spatula LATER -- Wendy, Jon and Kasia eat silently. After a moment, the sound of SNIFFLES. Wendy looks up from her plate and sees -- Jon tearing up with appreciation as he chews. Wendy and Kasia exchange a look. EXT. JON’S HOUSE - DAY 92 The COROLLA IDLES out front. Kasia climbs in as Jon loads the trunk with suitcases. Wendy stands in the doorway wearing a coat over her pajamas as she waves goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy and Jon, dressed in old T-shirts and Converse sneak chase the ball with their rackets.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: How'd it go at the airport?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Pine.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Was it emotional?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: She loves you.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... there are practical considerations that love has nothing to do with. Wendy races after the ball and lobs it over the net.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Like what? Her return goes way out of bounds. Jon shuffles across the court to retrieve the wayward ball.  58.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Wendy, do you have any idea how many Comp-Lit-Critical Theory PhDs there are running around this country looking for work? Even if Kasia and I did get married and she stayed, she could end up teaching at some university that’s farther away from here than Poland... and then we wouldn't be together either. See what I’m saying? Wendy makes a comically confused face.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You're an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: can we just play the game?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Pine. Jon hits the ball to Wendy. She returns it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got us an interview.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: A really nice alternative to the Valley View.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (irritated) We just got him in there!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: can you hold your judgements until you see this place. It’s beautiful. It’s called Greenhill Manor.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Sounds like an insane asylum. With a loud grunt, Jon hits an angry back-handed return, then suddenly drops his racket, grips the side of his neck and grimaces in pain...

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: oww!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Are you okay?  94 95 59.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (writhing) No, I am not okay!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Are you having a heart attack?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: No, Wendy I am not having a heart attack! (more pain) Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy stands at the sink filling up a medical-looking VINYL BAG with water.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (calling off-screen) How much do I fill it up?

dialogues.speaker: JON, (0S)
dialogues.text: ‘Twenty pounds. Wendy looks at the bag and sees MEASURING MARKS with numbers indicating poundage. She fills it to TWENTY.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOYER -. 95
dialogues.text: Wendy enters carrying the unwieldy bag of water. She arri before Jon who stands against the front door shirtless an wearing a strange HARNESS CONTRAPTION wrapped underneath chin and around his head. Cords and pulleys attached to i lead to a bracket that is hooked over the top of the door The overall effect is not unlike that of a man preparing hang himself.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What do I do with it?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (holding a rod) Hook it to this. Wendy attaches the water bag to the apparatus and then st back to observe the fully assembled contraption. The sigh of Jon hanging there makes Wendy laugh. This makes Jon start to laugh, but the laughing pains him further.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ow! Don't laugh. (Wendy laughs more) It's not funny.  96 60.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What's it supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Relieve pressure. I have to stay like this for thirty minutes. Wendy looks at her brother and, unable to contain herself, she lets out another round of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wendy! Give me my mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy hands him a pile of mail from a nearby table. He si through it and stops when he comes to A BUBBLE ENVELOPE.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is for you. (re: the return address) Who's Larry Mendelsohn? Wendy grabs it from him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (defensive) A friend... forwarding me my mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jon narrows his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Is that the married guy? Wendy heads toward the kitchen, leaving her brother pinned to the door.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I’m starving. You want something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I thought you stopped seeing that creep.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0S)
dialogues.text: How about tuna melts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (WO OPEN FACED TUNA MELTS glow in an ANCIENT TOASTER OVEN Wendy stands at the counter quickly sorting through her m and stops when she gets to A CERTAIN ENVELOPE. Turning it over in her hands, she carefully opens it and pulls out t letter.  97 61. CLOSE ON WENDY reading with great concentration. She is deeply engrossed and still for a long moment, then her eyes widen and her hand flutters to her mouth. She can’t believe what she is reading. It’s good news, but there seems to be a little hesitation as well. Then -- DING!!! the toaster oven bell startles her-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy enters, carrying her mail along with the TUNA MELTS.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (handing one to Jon) Here you go.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Mmm. Thanks. Jon takes the tuna melt and cautiously nibbles a corner. Wendy perches on the arm of a chair.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need you to spend Thanksgiving with Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We're not going to do it together?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: It’s my only time to get away for research.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well, I have things I have to do, too.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: (with a mouth full of tuna) Like what?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Like my life for instance in New York City.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Well, maybe it’s time to stop being so self’ involved and think about somebody else's life for a change.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh, like you who can’t put his book aside for one minute while dad dies.  62.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I have got to get this thing finished, Wendy. “My editor thinks it’s a good time for it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard everyone's really itching for & book about Bertolt Brecht this holiday season.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Wendy I'm working! Wendy is hurt. Tears well up against her will.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (tiny) working.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I know you are. I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I'm sorry. It’s just -- I got a lot riding on this book. And your life is much more portable than mine.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean? Like a toilet? Like a Porta-Potty?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: No. I’m just saying, you don’t have a job job. I do. I have obligations. You're... freelance. Couldn't you just hook up with a temp agency down here? Wendy is shaky. There is a warble in her voice. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Um -- actually -- Jon, I am being funded, right now... to work on my plays. And maybe that sounds a little -- self- involved -- but T also have an obligation to a prestigious foundation that has put a lot of faith in me -- and frankly, has given me a hell of a lot more support than he ever has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jon is quietly stunned.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: You got it?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What?  63.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: ‘The Guggenheim? Wendy sniffs back her tears and gets control of herself, but there is something measured about her response.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, really. why do you sound so surprised?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: I'm not. It’s just a really hard thing to get is all. “I’ve applied a half a dozen times and I never got one.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well, I did. And so did two hundred- something other people who are considered promising in their field or whatever. Why can’t you just be happy for me?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Iam. Iam, It’s great. (bewildered) ‘They must have like a whole different set of criteria for playwrights.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: ‘They like my work, Jon. They think I'm good. Is that so hard for you to believe? Jon I believe it. I just can’t believe you've been keeping it a secret.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I just found out.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Just now? Wendy nods yes and gestures to the mail in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god, that’s amazing. It’s really great, Wen. I’m really proud of you...  98 99 64.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's amazing. It’s major. Maybe this is your time, Wen. Your year. Look, how about we both work here and ride out the holidays together and get lots of writing done. It'll be fun. We can inspire each other. Our own little writers’ colony. After a moment, Wendy nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: JON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m really proud of you, Wen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Once in the foyer, he stiffly pulls on his coat, grabs his satchel and turns around to find -—~ A BULGING ENVELOPE Scotch-taped to the front door. A note on it says: Jon, these might help. Love, Wen. Jon removes a prescription pill bottle from the envelope. The label reads: Doris Metzger -- Percocet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy sleeps on the couch. Jon appears over her as he examines the vial.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Do they work? Wendy peels open her eyes and nods yes. Jon opens the vial, spills a pill in his hand, considers it for a moment and swigs back with a nearby bottle of water. He places the vial on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Don't forget that thing tonight. Jon gives her a pained look.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 101 102 65. Jon nods in agreement and leaves. Upon hearing the SOUND OF THE FRONT DOOR CLOSING, Wendy notices the bottle of Percocet Jon left behind and thinks, “Why not?” She smiles dreamily and reaches for the bottle.

dialogues.text: A NEEDLE IS PLACED ON AN ALBUM. ‘he Kinks play from the turntable. Wendy does a sexy, utterly private Percocet induced dance in the living room. INT. /EXT. dialogues.text: Larry lounges on the bed. INTERCUT.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No problem... Wen?

dialogues.text: I’m leaving town next week for a week. I won't be able to take care of Genghis.

dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.text: A female VOLUNTEER COUNSELOR in a colorful sweater conducts a support group. On a blackboard behind her it says: "Healing Through Reminiscence.”

dialogues.text: COUNSELOR (CONT’D) If you're ever at a loss for what to do on a visiting day with your elder, this list will come in very handy. The DOOR in the back opens to reveal Wendy and Jon.

dialogues.text: Okay, so. (reading from book) “creating Special Moments.” Number One: Ask your elder about the old days. dialogues.text: Excuse me -~ Wendy and Jon turn around, their mouths stuffed with food.

dialogues.speaker: COUNSELOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We haven't served refreshments yet. The whole room looks at them, indignant.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMALTZY MELODRAMATIC MUSIC PLAYS. A DOZEN OR SO

dialogues.text: (whispering) Is that your neighborhood, Dad?

dialogues.text: (mumbling) Yep. They got that right. Some STAFF stand in the back of the room ~~ KITCHEN WORKERS and a couple of NURSES. ON SCREEN -- a MOTHER cooks in a tenement kitchen.

dialogues.text: ‘There she is.

dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.text: ‘There's the bastard.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: (yelling at the screen) Bastard! MR. MCGILL, a perpetually disgruntled resident, asserts himself.

dialogues.text: Shut up up there.

dialogues.text: You shut yourself up. It’s my night.  7. Lenny pushes himself up and gestures at the screen.

dialogues.text: come on, Dad.

dialogues.text: (aggressively cheerful) Goodnight. As Wendy and Jon wait for the elevator, the group at the nurses station regards them with flat stares.

dialogues.text: Let's take the stairs. Jon exits and Wendy follows.

dialogues.text: Dad, open your mouth. Wendy puts the pills in Lenny’s mouth and holds a water bottle to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: JON
